Description: PROJECT SUMMARYTHE PROJECT PROPOSED WILL INCLUDE THE RESTORATION OF 3 SITES ON CHINCOTEAGUE NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE  VIRGINIA, USING NATURE-BASED SOLUTIONS. THE ENHANCEMENT OF LIGHTHOUSE MEADOW (4 ACRES), SOW POND (48 ACRES), AND ASSATEAGUE CHANNEL (30 ACRES) WILL RESULT IN 82 ACRES OF TIDAL SALT MARSH BEING RESTORED. THE PROJECT GOALS ARE TO RESTORE HISTORICAL HYDROLOGY TO MARSH HABITATS, BUILD RESILIENCY IN THE FACE OF MOUNTING THREATS, AND INCREASE HABITAT FOR MARSH NESTING BIRDS, FISH, AND SHELLFISH. THESE PROJECTS ALSO SERVE TO CREATE TEMPLATES OR DEMONSTRATION PROJECTS THAT CAN BUILD THE KNOWLEDGE BASE AND ACCEPTANCE WITHIN THE RESTORATION AND NATURAL RESOURCES COMMUNITY (ESPECIALLY ASSOCIATED WITH THE BENEFICIAL USE OF DREDGE MATERIAL AND ELEVATION ENHANCEMENT TO RECONSTRUCT DEGRADED OR LOST TIDAL WETLANDS). THESE GOALS WILL BE ATTAINED THROUGH THE (1) BREACH AND REMOVAL OF DIKE AND WATER CONTROL STRUCTURES ON IMPOUNDED WETLANDS TO REINTRODUCE TIDAL FLOW AND (2) THIN LAYER DEPOSITION OF SEDIMENT IN THE MARSH TO BUILD ELEVATION COUPLED WITH PLANTING OF VARIOUS MARSH GRASSES TO REESTABLISH THE MARSH PLATFORM.PROJECT ACTIVITIES, METHODS, AND TIMETABLE: PHASE I: PHASE I IS IDENTIFIED BY  1,699,309 OF FUNDS AVAILABLE IMMEDIATELY TO BEGIN A MULTI-PHASE, TIERFUNDEDAPPROACH TO THE PROJECTS PROPOSED AT CHINCOTEAGUE NWR. THIS INITIAL FUNDING IS CASH FUNDS FROM AVARIETY OF SOURCES INCLUDING HURRICANE SANDY RESILIENCY FUNDS AND HURRICANE SANDY RECOVERY FUNDS,SUPPLEMENTED BY IN-KIND VALUE FROM THE TOWN OF CHINCOTEAGUE, CHINCOTEAGUE NWR, AND USFWSECOLOGICALSERVICES RESTORATION DIVISION. FUNDS ARE AVAILABLE IMMEDIATELY TO COMPLETE ALL PROPOSEDACTIVITIES ON 52 ACRES AT SOW POND AND LIGHTHOUSE MEADOW AT AN EXPECTED COST OF  518,997. WITH THEREMAINING  1,180,312 OF FUNDS AFTER THE COMPLETION OF SOW POND AND LIGHTHOUSE MEADOWS, WE WILL ALSOBEGIN IMPLEMENTATION OF THE ASSATEAGUE CHANNEL RESTORATION AND EXPECT TO COMPLETE 14.25 ACRES OFRESTORATION WORK.PHASE II: PHASE II IS IDENTIFIED BY  500,000 OF FUNDING THAT WILL BECOME AVAILABLE IN FY24, BY THEUSFWS, TO FURTHER IMPLEMENT RESTORATION ACTIVITIES ON ASSATEAGUE CHANNEL. 6.21 ACRES OF RESTORATION WORKPLANNED AT ASSATEAGUE CHANNEL WILL BE COMPLETED IN PHASE II, WITH EXPECTED COMPLETION IN FY 25.PHASE III: IMPLEMENTATION OF THE FINAL PHASE (PHASE III) OF THE PROJECT IS DEPENDENT ON SECURINGNECESSARY FUNDING, AND ON THE COSTS AND SOURCES OF THE NEEDED SEDIMENT. WE EXPECT THE TOTAL COSTS OFPHASE III TO BE  770,967, THUS COMPLETING THE REMAINING 9.6 ACRES OF THE ASSATEAGUE CHANNEL RESTORATION.PHASE III COULD OCCUR CONCURRENT WITH PHASE II IF THE NECESSARY FUNDING IS SECURED, OR NOT GET IMPLEMENTEDUNTIL FUTURE YEARS AS FUNDING IS IDENTIFIED.WHEN AND IF PHASE III IS COMPLETED NO SUBSEQUENT ACTIVITIES ARE ANTICIPATED.

THIS PROJECT WILL EVALUATE THE CONSEQUENCES OF SEDIMENT ADDITIONS TO COASTAL MARSHES FOR SALTMARSH NESTING BIRDS, AND WILL HELP IMPROVE THE DEVELOPMENT OF BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES AND INFORM THE ATLANTIC COAST JOINT VENTURE S SALT MARSH BIRD CONSERVATION PLAN  SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL COLLECT DATA AT THE STRATFORD GREAT MEADOWS MARSH RESTORATION PROJECT AND AT A NEARBY REFERENCE SITE  WE WILL TRACK SPARROW BREEDING BEHAVIOR AND HABITAT USE OF THESE SITES USING PRE EXISTING PROTOCOLS AND NEW TRACKING TECHNOLOGIES TO OBTAIN DETAILED INFORMATION ON THE WAY IN WHICH HABITAT IS USED  WE WILL USE THE RESULTING DATA TO  A  ESTIMATE RATES OF VEGETATION REGROWTH FOLLOWING SEDIMENT ADDITIONS,  B  DESCRIBE SPARROW NEST SELECTION AND SUCCESS IN RELATION TO RESTORATION ACTIVITIES, AND  C  QUANTIFY ANY SHORT TERM CHANGE IN RESTORATION SITE PRODUCTIVITY POST RESTORATION  THE WORK WILL BE FULLY INTEGRATED WITH EXISTING RESEARCH BY THE SALTMARSH HABITAT AND AVIAN RESEARCH PROGRAM  SHARP  TO ENSURE THAT DATA SETS CAN BE COMBINED AND ALL DATA WILL BE ENTERED INTO A REGIONAL DATABASE FOR DEMOGRAPHIC INFORMATION RECENTLY CREATED BY SHARP

THE PROJECT WILL IMPLEMENT POST-CONSTRUCTION ADAPTIVE MANAGEMENT TECHNIQUES AT THE GREAT MEADOWS MARSH UNIT OF THE S.B. MCKINNEY NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGE. SPECIFIC TECHNIQUES WILL INCLUDE INVASIVE SPECIES CONTROL THROUGH THE USE OF HERBICIDES, PLANTING AND SEEDING OF NATIVE MARSH AND COASTAL PLANT SPECIES, APPLICATION OF GRAVEL TO TRAILS AND BUILDING ADA ACCESSIBLE RAMPS FOR THE VIEWING PLATFORMS, EMPLOYING URBAN YOUTH TO ACT AS SALT MARSH STEWARDS, AND MONITORING THE RESULTS OF THE RESTORATION.THE IMMEDIATE POPULATION CENTERS THAT THE PROJECT WILL SERVE ARE THE CITIES OF BRIDGEPORT AND STRATFORD, CONNECTICUT. THE LARGER COMMUNITY INCLUDES MEMBERS OF THE POPULATION WHO ENJOY PASSIVE RECREATIONAL ACTIVATES IN SOUTHWESTERN COASTAL CONNECTICUT. THE IMPACTS WILL BE POSITIVE AND INCLUDE AN INCREASE IN COASTAL RESILIENCY, IMPROVEMENT IN HABITAT FOR VULNERABLE COASTAL SPECIES, ENGAGEMENT WITH THE PUBLIC FROM NEARBY URBAN ENVIRONMENTAL JUSTICE COMMUNITIES, INCREASED ACCESS FOR DISABLED CITIZENS, AND INCREASED KNOWLEDGE THAT CAN BE APPLIED TO FUTURE COASTAL RESTORATION PROJECTS.

THE PROJECT TEAM OF U.S. FISH AND WILDLIFE SERVICE AND DUCKS UNLIMITED, INC. (DU) INTEND TO IMPLEMENT A COMBINATION OF TRADITIONAL AND INNOVATIVE NATURE BASED TIDAL WETLAND RESTORATION METHODS THAT WILL IMPROVE HABITAT ON TWO NATIONAL WILDLIFE REFUGES IN THE DELAWARE BAY. THE EMPLOYED RESTORATION METHODS ARE INTENDED TO ALLOW THE SYSTEMS TO EVOLVE IN A MORE NATURAL BALANCE WITH THE CHANGING CONDITIONS, RATHER THAN FIGHTING OR BEING DESIGNED TO STOP THE NATURAL EVOLUTION OF THE COASTAL DYNAMICS. THE SETTINGS HAVE ALL BEEN HEAVILY IMPACTED BY ANTHROPOGENIC INFLUENCES WHICH HAVE DECOUPLED THE NATURAL PROCESSES THAT PROMOTE NATURAL RESILIENCY. THE INNOVATIVE METHODS BEING UTILIZED WERE RECENTLY ESTABLISHED BY PILOT AND/OR SMALLER SCALE PROJECTS. THESE PROJECTS WILL IMPLEMENT INNOVATIVE METHODS FOR THE FIRST TIME IN DE BAY OR AT THE LARGEST SCALES KNOWN TO DATE ALONG THE ATLANTIC COAST, AND POSSIBLY, NATIONALLY.
